templates.title: Security Audit (≤3 years)
templates.description: Information security audit at least every 3 years (submit report to the Agency within 1 month)
templates.recommendation: Plan and complete an information security audit; submit the audit report to the National Cybersecurity Agency within 1 month
templates.help_text: Independent review of how well your security measures meet the regulation’s annex requirements
templates.why_matters: Confirms your real level of conformity, finds blind spots before inspectors or attackers do, and is explicitly required on a 3-year cycle.

info.what_it_means: A formal information security audit that evaluates your conformity with the Government Decision’s annexed security measures. The audit should be objective and competent (typically by an independent internal audit function or an external auditor). Findings are documented in an audit report.
info.why_it_matters: Audits provide evidence that required measures are implemented and effective. They surface gaps for remediation, reduce enforcement risk, and demonstrate due care to customers and partners.
law_refs: HG NU-49-MDED-2025, pct. 9 (audit at least every 3 years; report due to the Agency in 1 month)
Legea nr. 48/2023, art. 11(2) pct. 6 (verifying completeness incl. via security audits)

resources.title: ISO 19011 — Guidelines for auditing management systems (overview)
IAF CertSearch — find accredited certification bodies

attack_vectors: Controls drift (measures not implemented as designed)
Unnoticed misconfigurations or outdated systems
Unmanaged third-party/supply-chain exposures
potential_impact: Regulatory non-conformity and sanctions
Service disruption or data compromise
Loss of trust and contracts due to weak assurance

non_technical_steps: Define audit scope aligned to the annex measures and your service footprint.
Select a competent, independent auditor (internal audit or external provider).
Prepare evidence pack: policies, risk assessment, logs/retention, backup tests, IAM reviews, incident process, etc.
Hold the audit: interviews, sampling, control testing, evidence verification.
Receive report, classify findings by risk, and create a remediation plan with owners & deadlines.
Submit the audit report (and any independent examination reports) to the Agency within 1 month of completion.
Track remediation to closure and schedule the next audit (≤3 years, or sooner if required).
guide.scope_caveats: The audit must cover the security measures applicable to your services and systems. If parts are out of scope, document and justify them.
guide.acceptance_summary: An on-time audit and report demonstrate active conformity management. The Agency may still review or request additional evidence.

legal.requirement_summary: You must perform information security audits at least once every 3 years (or more often if the annex requires) and submit the audit report to the National Cybersecurity Agency within 1 month of completion.

quotes.text: Furnizorii de servicii efectuează audituri privind securitatea informațiilor… cel puțin o dată la trei ani… Raportul de audit… se prezintă Agenției… în termen de o lună de la data efectuării.

templates.title: ISO 27001 Certification
templates.description: Valid ISO/IEC 27001:2022 information security management system certification
templates.recommendation: Obtain ISO/IEC 27001:2022 certification from an accredited certification body
templates.help_text: International certification that can substitute detailed compliance requirements when presented to authorities
templates.why_matters: Valid ISO 27001 certification can exempt organizations from detailed annex security measures under Moldova's regulations, while providing systematic security management.

info.what_it_means: ISO/IEC 27001:2022 is the international ISMS standard. Certification is granted by an accredited body after a two-stage audit (Stage 1 = documentation/readiness; Stage 2 = implementation/effectiveness). Certificates typically cover a defined scope (services, locations) and are issued for three years with annual surveillance.
info.why_it_matters: Shows you manage security risks systematically (policies, risk treatment, controls, continuous improvement). Builds trust, shortens due-diligence, and—under Moldova’s implementing regulation—can exempt you from the detailed annex measures if you hold a valid SM ISO/IEC 27001 certificate filed with the Agency. The Agency may still review you.
law_refs: HG NU-49-MDED-2025, pct. 10 (SM ISO/IEC 27001 certificate may substitute annex measures)
HG NU-49-MDED-2025, pct. 9 (security audits at least once every 3 years)
Legea nr. 48/2023, art. 11(4)(a) (Guvernul asigură aprobarea standardelor naționale)

resources.title: HG NU-49-MDED-2025 — Regulament de aplicare (PDF oficial)
ENISA — Implementation guidance on security measures (NIS2)
SBS (UE) — Ghid pentru IMM-uri: implementarea ISO/IEC 27001 (PDF)
NCSC (UK) — Small Business Guide to Cyber Security
IAF CertSearch — verifică certificate ISO acreditate

attack_vectors: Lack of systematic security management creates uncontrolled gaps
Weak or ad-hoc risk assessment misses critical exposures
Controls not implemented or maintained consistently across scope
potential_impact: Regulatory non-compliance and penalties
Security breaches due to unmanaged risks
Loss of customer trust and contracts

non_technical_steps: Define ISMS scope (services, locations, assets)
Do a gap analysis vs. ISO/IEC 27001:2022
Establish policy set and governance roles
Run risk assessment & risk treatment plan
Map and implement Annex A controls as needed
Launch awareness/training and internal audit cycle
Management review → Stage 1 & Stage 2 certification audits
Maintain continuous improvement (surveillance audits yearly)
guide.scope_caveats: Certification applies only to the defined ISMS scope. Ensure all relevant processes, systems, and third parties are included.
guide.acceptance_summary: A valid SM ISO/IEC 27001 certificate filed with the Agency can substitute the annex measures; the Agency can still evaluate your conformity.

legal.requirement_summary: With a valid SM ISO/IEC 27001 certificate presented to the Agency, the annex security-measure requirements of the Government Decision do not apply; however, the Agency reserves the right to assess conformity. Independent security audits must be performed at least every 3 years.

quotes.text: Cerințele prevăzute în anexă nu se aplică furnizorilor de servicii dacă… sunt conforme cu… SM ISO/IEC 27001 și… a prezentat… un certificat valabil.
Furnizorii de servicii efectuează audituri… cel puțin o dată la trei ani

templates.title: Last Security Awareness Training
templates.description: Date of most recent cybersecurity training for employees
templates.recommendation: Provide periodic, role-based cybersecurity awareness training and track completion
templates.help_text: All staff (incl. management, relevant suppliers) should receive recurring training; new starters must be covered promptly
templates.why_matters: People are the first line of defense. Well-trained employees spot phishing, handle data safely, and react correctly to incidents.

info.what_it_means: An organization-wide, planned program that repeatedly trains staff on cyber risks, safe behavior, and how to act on security events. It must align with your security policies, cover new hires, be role-based for sensitive functions, and its effectiveness should be evaluated and updated periodically.
info.why_it_matters: Most incidents start with human error or social engineering. A structured, recurring program measurably reduces risk and is explicitly required by Moldova’s implementing regulation and the law’s mandate for cyber hygiene and training.
law_refs: HG NU-49-MDED-2025, Cap. VIII, pct. 94–96 (Sensibilizare/igienă cibernetică)
HG NU-49-MDED-2025, Cap. VIII, pct. 97–99 (Formare rol-bazată, evaluarea eficacității)
Legea nr. 48/2023, art. 11 alin. (2) pct. 2) lit. i) (igienă cibernetică și formare)

resources.title: CIS Controls — Security Awareness & Skills Training

attack_vectors: Phishing/social engineering trick staff into revealing credentials
Unsafe handling of data and devices
Delayed or wrong response to security events
potential_impact: Account takeover and ransomware
Personal/data breach and regulatory penalties
Service outages, reputational damage, lost revenue

non_technical_steps: Appoint an owner; define audience groups and roles (e.g., finance, admins).
Publish a short Training Policy and a 12-month Plan (sessions + onboarding).
Map topics to risks and policies (phishing, passwords/MFA, data handling, incident reporting).
Deliver short, frequent modules; ensure new starters are trained within their first month.
Run simple effectiveness checks (quizzes, simulated phishing) and track completion.
Update content at planned intervals based on incidents/threats and collect feedback.
Keep evidence: policy, plan, materials, attendance/logs, quiz/simulation stats, updates.
guide.scope_caveats: Training must cover all staff and relevant suppliers where appropriate; some roles need deeper, role-specific training (e.g., admins, incident responders).
guide.acceptance_summary: Regulator will look for a documented, repeated, role-based program that aligns to your policies, covers new hires, and is evaluated for effectiveness.

legal.requirement_summary: Mandatory: a planned, recurring awareness program for all staff (including new hires) aligned with security policy; role-based training where needed; evaluate effectiveness and keep it up to date.
article_refs: Legea nr. 48/2023: art. 11(2) pct. 2) lit. i)

quotes.text: Angajații… sunt sensibilizați… și aplică practici de igienă cibernetică.
Programul de sensibilizare este planificat… repetat și acoperă noii angajați.
Formarea trebuie să fie relevantă pentru funcția postului… iar eficacitatea sa trebuie să fie evaluată.

templates.title: Backup Strategy Documented
templates.description: Formal backup and recovery procedures are documented
templates.recommendation: Document your backup strategy and test it regularly
templates.help_text: Written procedures for backing up and restoring critical data
templates.why_matters: Ensures business continuity in case of data loss or ransomware attacks

info.what_it_means: A written plan that defines what data is backed up, how often, where backups are stored (including offsite/offline copies), who is responsible, retention periods, encryption, and how restores are tested—plus target recovery time (RTO) and recovery point (RPO).
info.why_it_matters: Backups (with redundancy) are a legal expectation and the only reliable way to recover from ransomware, deletion, or disasters. The plan must include integrity checks and periodic restore tests so recovery actually works when needed.
law_refs: Legea nr. 48/2023, art. 11 alin. (2) lit. e) — măsuri privind continuitatea activității și gestionarea crizelor
HG NU-49-MDED-2025, pct. 39–41 — Plan de continuitate și plan de recuperare în caz de dezastru (BIA, testare, revizuire)
HG NU-49-MDED-2025, pct. 42–47 — Gestionarea copiilor de rezervă și a redundanței (planuri de rezervă, stocare separată, controale de acces, verificări de integritate, testarea recuperării)

resources.title: UK NCSC — Backing up your data (plain-English guide)
NIST SP 800-184 — Guide for Cybersecurity Event Recovery

attack_vectors: Ransomware encrypts production AND online backups
Accidental deletion or insider error without recoverable copies
Site outage or disaster with no offsite/offline backups
potential_impact: Prolonged outage and revenue loss
Irreversible loss of critical data
Regulatory non-compliance and reputational damage

non_technical_steps: Identify critical data/systems and set business RTO/RPO targets (simple table).
Choose a 3-2-1 approach: 3 copies, 2 different media/locations, 1 offline or immutable.
Define encryption (in transit/at rest), access controls, and backup ownership/roles.
Write a retention schedule (business & legal needs) and document storage locations.
Schedule integrity checks and a quarterly restore test; record results and fixes.
Document a simple recovery playbook: who does what, in what order, from where.
Review after incidents or major changes; update plan and train staff.
guide.acceptance_summary: Compliant if you have a written backup & recovery plan covering scope, RTO/RPO, storage (including off-network/offsite), encryption & access controls, retention, integrity checks, and evidence of successful restore tests on a regular schedule.

legal.requirement_summary: You must keep backups and ensure adequate redundancy; set backup plans driven by risk and BCP, store copies safely (separate network/location), control access, check integrity, and test recovery periodically. BCP/DR plans must be tested and updated.
article_refs: Legea nr. 48/2023, art. 11 alin. (2) lit. e)

quotes.text: Furnizorii de servicii păstrează copii de rezervă ale datelor… pentru a asigura un nivel adecvat de redundanță.
…planuri de rezervă, care includ: termenele de recuperare… stocarea de copii de rezervă… într-un loc… care nu se află în aceeași rețea…
Furnizorii de servicii testează periodic recuperarea copiilor de rezervă.

templates.title: Last Successful Restore Test
templates.description: Recent test of backup restoration procedures
templates.recommendation: Test backup restoration procedures at least quarterly (and after major changes/incidents)
templates.help_text: When did you last verify that backups can be successfully restored?
templates.why_matters: Backups are only useful if you can restore them within target time (RTO) and with acceptable data loss (RPO). Regular testing proves recoverability and prevents nasty surprises during a real incident.

info.what_it_means: A planned, documented exercise where you restore data/systems from backup into a safe environment and verify integrity, completeness, and time-to-recover against your RTO/RPO. Include different test types (file-level, database point-in-time, full system/app) and evidence of results and fixes.
info.why_it_matters: Un-tested backups often fail when needed (corruption, missing keys, wrong scope, too slow). Periodic restore testing is required by the implementing regulation and validates that your business can actually recover from ransomware, deletion, or outages.
law_refs: HG NU-49-MDED-2025, pct. 47 (testarea periodică a recuperării copiilor de rezervă)
HG NU-49-MDED-2025, pct. 39–41 (plan de continuitate și testare)
Legea nr. 48/2023, art. 11(2) lit. e) (continuitatea activității și gestionarea crizelor)
Legea nr. 48/2023, art. 11(2) lit. d) (evaluarea eficacității măsurilor de securitate)

resources.title: NCSC (UK) — Backing up your data (includes testing)
NIST SP 800-184 — Guide for Cybersecurity Event Recovery

attack_vectors: Ransomware encrypts production and online backups (no offline/immutable copy)
Corrupted or incomplete backups discovered only during a real incident
Credentials/keys for backup or decryption missing at restore time
Restore takes longer than RTO or cannot meet point-in-time objective (RPO)
potential_impact: Extended outage and financial loss
Permanent data loss and regulatory exposure
Reputational damage and breach notifications

non_technical_steps: Publish a simple Restore Test Plan: scope, frequency, roles, RTO/RPO targets.
Select representative scenarios: file restore, DB point-in-time, full app/system.
Restore into an isolated/safe environment; never overwrite production.
Verify integrity (hash/row counts), app functionality, user access, dependencies.
Measure actual RTO/RPO vs targets; record gaps and root causes.
Produce a short Test Report with screenshots/logs and a corrective action list.
Retest after material changes or incidents; keep evidence for audits.
guide.scope_caveats: Tests must reflect your critical services and include at least one full restore scenario. Include offline/immutable backup sources where applicable.
guide.acceptance_summary: Compliant if you have a dated Restore Test Report (≤ 3–6 months old) showing scope, steps, environment, integrity checks, measured RTO/RPO, results (PASS/FAIL), issues found, corrective actions, and sign-off.

legal.requirement_summary: You must test recovery of backups periodically as part of business continuity; plans must be tested and updated. Testing evidences the effectiveness of the security measures.

quotes.text: Furnizorii de servicii testează periodic recuperarea copiilor de rezervă.
Planurile de continuitate și recuperare se testează și se revizuiesc periodic.

templates.title: Cybersecurity Policy
templates.description: Formal cybersecurity policy document approved by management
templates.recommendation: Develop, approve, publish, and review a comprehensive cybersecurity policy at least annually
templates.help_text: A written policy covering scope, roles, responsibilities, mandatory controls, exceptions, approval, and review cycle
templates.why_matters: Sets the rules for how your organization protects information and meets legal obligations; gives staff clear guidance and auditors clear evidence.

info.what_it_means: A top-level, approved document that defines your security objectives, scope (who/what it applies to), roles and responsibilities, and the mandatory requirements your organization follows (risk management, incident response, access control, cryptography, logging/monitoring, continuity/DR, supplier security, awareness). It references underlying procedures/standards and states how exceptions are requested and who approves them.
info.why_it_matters: Without a policy, security is ad-hoc. A signed, communicated policy proves leadership commitment, aligns staff and suppliers, and is required under Moldova’s Cybersecurity Law (policies and procedures across risk, incidents, crypto, effectiveness reviews, continuity, HR/access, hygiene, secure communications).
law_refs: Legea nr. 48/2023, art. 11(2) pct. 2) lit. a)–j) (politici/proceduri: risc, incidente, criptografie, evaluarea eficacității, continuitate/BCP, resurse umane & control acces, lanț de aprovizionare, igienă cibernetică & formare, autentificare & comunicații securizate)
HG NU-49-MDED-2025 (cerințe organizatorice: politici aprobate, roluri/ responsabilități, actualizare periodică, evidențe de conformitate)

resources.title: NCSC (UK) — Create or improve your cyber security policies
CIS Controls v8 — Governance & Policy starters (IG1)

attack_vectors: Inconsistent practices and shadow IT due to unclear rules
Role confusion during incidents and access provisioning
Gaps in crypto, logging, backups because expectations aren’t defined
potential_impact: Regulatory non-conformity and sanctions
Longer, costlier incidents due to chaos and unclear authority
Loss of customer trust and failed audits

non_technical_steps: Appoint an owner (CISO/IT lead) and an approver (CEO/Board).
Define scope & applicability (employees, contractors, systems, data).

Structure the policy: Purpose; Scope; Roles & Responsibilities; Mandatory Requirements (risk mgmt, incidents, access/MFA, crypto, logging, backups/DR, vendor security, awareness); Exceptions; Enforcement; Review.
Reference supporting procedures/standards (e.g., Incident Response Plan, Access Control Standard, Backup/DR Plan).
Set review cycle (at least annually and after major changes/incidents) and version control.
Communicate: publish internally; capture employee acknowledgement for new starters.
Keep evidence: signed approval page/minutes, version history, change log, distribution/acknowledgement record.
guide.scope_caveats: Keep it concise (3–6 pages) and policy-level; put step-by-step instructions in separate procedures. If you outsource IT, include supplier responsibilities and minimum controls.
guide.acceptance_summary: Compliant if you can show a signed, in-date policy (≤12 months), clear roles, mandatory requirements mapped to the law, references to procedures, exception process, and proof it was communicated to staff.

legal.requirement_summary: Maintain approved, current security policies and procedures covering (at minimum) risk analysis, incident management, cryptography, control effectiveness evaluation, continuity/DR, HR security & access control, supply-chain security, cyber hygiene & training, and secure authentication/communications.
article_refs: Legea nr. 48/2023, art. 11(2) pct. 2) lit. a)–j)
HG NU-49-MDED-2025 (cerințe organizatorice privind politici, roluri, revizuire)

templates.title: Risk Assessment Documentation
templates.description: Documented cybersecurity risk assessment for your organization
templates.recommendation: Conduct and document a formal cybersecurity risk assessment; keep a living risk register and treatment plan
templates.help_text: Upload your latest risk assessment report and risk register (with treatment plan, owners, deadlines, and residual risk sign-off).
templates.why_matters: This is a core legal obligation. It drives what controls you prioritize, how you mitigate risks, and what residual risks leadership accepts.

info.what_it_means: A structured process and report that IDENTIFIES assets and third-party dependencies; MAPS threats, vulnerabilities, and single points of failure; ESTIMATES likelihood and impact; RATES risks; SELECTS and PRIORITIZES treatment options; ASSIGNS owners and deadlines; TRACKS residual risk with management approval. Output = Risk Assessment Report + Risk Register + Risk Treatment Plan.
info.why_it_matters: Required by Moldova’s cyber law and implementing decision. It proves you manage risk systematically, supports budgeting and board oversight, and underpins audits, continuity planning, and incident thresholds.
law_refs: Legea nr. 48/2023, art. 11(2) pct. 1 (evaluarea vulnerabilităților și riscurilor și raport de evaluare)
HG NU-49-MDED-2025, cap. II, pct. 5–8 (evaluări de risc documentate, plan de tratare, criterii, toleranță, actualizare cel puțin anual)

resources.title: NIST SP 800-30 Rev.1 – Guide for Conducting Risk Assessments

attack_vectors: Unmapped internet-facing services or single points of failure
Third-party/vendor dependencies not assessed
Legacy systems without owners or patch paths
potential_impact: Service outages or data breaches with significant impact
Regulatory non-compliance during supervision or audits
Poor prioritization wastes security budget on low-value controls

non_technical_steps: Define scope (services, locations, systems, third parties).
Set risk criteria (likelihood/impact scales), risk appetite & tolerance.
Inventory assets and internet-exposed services; note single points of failure.
Identify threats & vulnerabilities; include third-party and supply-chain risks.
Analyze & evaluate risk (likelihood × impact) and rank a top-N list.
Choose treatment per risk: avoid, mitigate (controls), transfer, or accept.
Create a Risk Treatment Plan (control, owner, deadline, success metric).
Record residual risk and obtain management sign-off.
Review & update at least annually and after major changes/incidents.
guide.scope_caveats: Assess the full service chain (internal + suppliers). Document assumptions and exclusions—auditors will check them.
guide.acceptance_summary: Residual risks must be explicitly accepted by management with traceable justification; revisit after changes or incidents.

legal.requirement_summary: You must perform and DOCUMENT risk assessments, establish and monitor a risk treatment plan, define risk criteria/tolerance, and update at least annually and after significant changes or incidents.

quotes.text: Furnizorii de servicii efectuează și documentează evaluări ale riscurilor și, pe baza rezultatelor, stabilesc, pun în aplicare și monitorizează un plan de tratare a riscurilor.
…identifică, analizează, evaluează, tratează riscurile; stabilesc toleranța la risc, criterii relevante; documentează măsurile într-un plan de tratare și motivele acceptării riscurilor reziduale.
…examinează și, dacă este adecvat, actualizează rezultatele evaluării riscurilor și planul de tratare… cel puțin o dată pe an sau la modificări semnificative ori incidente cu impact semnificativ.

templates.title: MFA for Privileged Accounts
templates.description: Multi-factor authentication enabled for administrator and privileged user accounts
templates.recommendation: Enable MFA for all administrator and privileged accounts immediately
templates.help_text: All admin accounts should require at least two authentication factors
templates.why_matters: Prevents unauthorized access even if passwords are compromised

info.what_it_means: Users with administrative or other high-impact privileges must authenticate with two or more independent factors (e.g., password + authenticator app, hardware key, smartcard). The Government’s implementing rules require secure authentication and say users should be authenticated by multiple factors or continuous authentication, aligned to the classification of the asset being accessed. Admin/privileged access must use separate credentials.
info.why_it_matters: Privileged accounts are the primary target in most breaches. MFA drastically reduces successful phishing, credential stuffing, and password reuse attacks, and is often required by customers and regulators.
law_refs: HG NU-49-MDED-2025: pct. 129 (identity lifecycle), pct. 130–133 (secure authentication controls), pct. 134–135 (multifactor/continuous authentication per asset classification), pct. 131.6 (separate credentials for privileged/admin access)
Legea nr. 48/2023: art. 11(2) lit. g), j) (controlul accesului; soluții de autentificare)

resources.title: NCSC-UK: Multi-factor authentication (MFA) for online services
Microsoft Entra ID: Plan and deploy MFA

attack_vectors: Phishing and credential theft against admins
Password reuse/credential stuffing on privileged accounts
Session hijacking without step-up authentication
potential_impact: Full domain or cloud tenant compromise
Data exfiltration and ransomware deployment
Service outages and regulatory penalties

non_technical_steps: Inventory privileged roles (domain admins, cloud tenant admins, root owners, billing, CI/CD, backups).
Turn on MFA tenant-wide and require it at least for all privileged roles/groups.
Prefer phishing-resistant factors (FIDO2/WebAuthn keys or smartcards) for admins.
Enforce separate admin credentials; prohibit everyday browsing/email on admin accounts.
Require step-up MFA for high-risk actions (e.g., policy changes, new keys, break-glass use).
Create emergency break-glass accounts (2), protect offline, test quarterly.
Monitor and alert on MFA disablements, factor resets, and failed admin logins.
Review MFA coverage monthly; re-certify privileged access quarterly.
guide.scope_caveats: MFA strength must match the sensitivity/classification of the asset being accessed. At minimum, privileged/admin access should always require MFA.
guide.acceptance_summary: Conforms when privileged/admin accounts use MFA with separate credentials and tenant policies enforce secure authentication in line with asset classification; procedures are documented and reviewed.

legal.requirement_summary: Providers must implement secure authentication; users should be authenticated with multiple factors (or continuous mechanisms) according to the asset’s classification, and privileged/admin access must use separate credentials. Authentication procedures and technologies must be reviewed periodically.
article_refs: Legea nr. 48/2023: art. 11(2) lit. g), j)

quotes.text: Furnizorii de servicii pun în aplicare proceduri și tehnologii de autentificare securizată…
…solicită acreditări separate pentru a obține acces privilegiat sau a avea acces la conturi administrative.
Furnizorii de servicii se asigură că utilizatorii sunt autentificați prin factori de autentificare multipli… în conformitate cu clasificarea activului…

templates.title: Regular Access Reviews
templates.description: Periodic review of user access rights and permissions
templates.recommendation: Establish a quarterly access review process with documented outcomes and revocations
templates.help_text: At planned intervals (e.g., quarterly), each system owner reviews who has access, why, and approves/removes access. Keep an access registry and record evidence of changes.
templates.why_matters: Prevents privilege creep, orphaned accounts, and excessive permissions. Confirms least-privilege access based on role and current employment/contract status.

info.what_it_means: A scheduled, documented review where system/data owners verify every user’s access (employees, contractors, third-parties, service accounts) remains necessary, appropriately scoped, and approved. Results are recorded and access is adjusted (modified/revoked) as needed.
info.why_it_matters: Access accumulates over time. Reviews reduce the risk of misuse or breach, ensure leavers/movers lose unneeded rights, and keep evidence of control operation for auditors and the Agency.
law_refs: GD NU-49-MDED-2025: pts. 118–120 (grant/modify/remove, keep registry, journalize, review at planned intervals)
GD NU-49-MDED-2025: pts. 121–123 (privileged/admin accounts: strong auth incl. MFA, dedicated admin accounts, planned reviews)
GD NU-49-MDED-2025: pts. 115–117 (documented access control policy; only authenticated users get access; policy reviewed periodically)

resources.title: NCSC (UK) — Managing user accounts and permissions
CIS Controls v8 — Control 6: Access Control Management

attack_vectors: Orphaned or stale accounts remain active after role change or termination
Excessive permissions enable lateral movement and data exfiltration
Shared/admin accounts without MFA are abused
potential_impact: Unauthorized access to sensitive systems/data
Regulatory non-compliance and sanctions
Fraud or service disruption due to privilege misuse

non_technical_steps: Inventory systems in scope and assign an accountable owner for each.
Export current user/role lists (employees, contractors, third-parties, service accounts).
Define review schedule (e.g., quarterly; more frequent for privileged access).
For each system, owner validates business need, least privilege, and SoD (segregation of duties).
Record outcomes: approved, modify (new role/scope), revoke; capture dates and approver.
Apply changes promptly; update the central Access Registry and keep an audit trail.
Document exceptions with compensating controls and review next cycle.
Report completion metrics and residual risks to management.
guide.scope_caveats: Include joiners/movers/leavers, contractors and vendors, shared/admin and service accounts, break-glass accounts, and third-party integrations. Keep evidence (review lists, approvals, change tickets).
guide.acceptance_summary: Evidence should show date, systems covered, reviewers, decisions (approve/modify/revoke), changes applied, updated Access Registry, and handling of exceptions. Privileged access must also show MFA and use of dedicated admin accounts.

legal.requirement_summary: Maintain and periodically review access rights; grant/modify/remove per policy; keep a registry and journal of access-right changes; review privileged/admin access on a planned cadence with strong authentication and dedicated admin accounts.

quotes.text: Furnizorii de servicii revizuiesc drepturile de acces la intervale planificate… și documentează rezultatele revizuirii.
Atribuie și revocă drepturi de acces pe baza… privilegiului minim și separării sarcinilor.
Țin un registru al drepturilor de acces acordate… [și] aplică jurnalizarea gestionării drepturilor de acces.

templates.title: Centralized Security Logging
templates.description: Security events are logged in a centralized system
templates.recommendation: Implement centralized logging for all critical systems
templates.help_text: All security-relevant events should be collected in one place
templates.why_matters: Enables rapid detection, triage and investigation of incidents; supports legal retention and audit requirements.

info.what_it_means: Set up procedures and tooling (e.g., SIEM or log aggregator) to collect, store and review security-relevant events from servers, applications, endpoints, network devices and cloud services in one searchable place. Keep clocks synchronized, protect logs from tampering, keep them at least 12 months, and review them regularly with alert thresholds.
info.why_it_matters: Without centralized logs you miss early indicators of attack (failed logons, privilege abuse, suspicious network traffic) and you can't reconstruct what happened. Central logging is explicitly required (monitoring & logging, periodic review, ≥12-month retention) and underpins incident classification, response and reporting.

non_technical_steps: Name an owner and approve a simple logging policy
Inventory what must be logged (systems, apps, devices)
Choose a central solution (managed SIEM or self-hosted aggregator)
Enable time sync (NTP) everywhere
Forward required events (auth, admin activity, access, network, security tools)
Set retention ≥12 months and protect logs from edits/deletion
Define alert thresholds and who responds
Review dashboards weekly; do a monthly trend review
Test access to historical logs quarterly; fix gaps
guide.acceptance_summary: Central place receives required events from in-scope assets; clocks are synchronized; alerts and reviews are defined; logs are protected and retained ≥12 months; periodic re-examination and asset list maintained.
guide.scope_caveats: Start with critical systems and expand. Cloud services (M365, Google Workspace, AWS, Azure, payment gateways) must also forward security logs.

legal.requirement_summary: You must monitor and log activities to detect events that may be incidents, review logs periodically, set alarm thresholds, retain and back up logs for a predefined period (not less than 12 months), synchronize time sources, maintain a list of logged assets, ensure redundancy, and re-examine procedures and the asset list regularly.

templates.title: SPF/DKIM/DMARC Implementation
templates.description: Email authentication protocols are properly configured
templates.recommendation: Configure SPF, DKIM, and DMARC records for your email domain
templates.help_text: These protocols help prevent email spoofing and phishing attacks
templates.why_matters: Protects your domain from being abused in phishing and improves deliverability; aligns with legal expectations for secure communications, cryptography use, and basic cyber hygiene.

info.what_it_means: SPF lists your authorized mail senders in DNS; DKIM adds a cryptographic signature to your emails (public key in DNS); DMARC tells receivers how to handle messages that fail alignment (p=none/quarantine/reject) and sends you aggregate/forensic reports (rua/ruf).
info.why_it_matters: Stops easy domain spoofing, reduces phishing risk for your customers and staff, and shows you manage communications security using authentication and cryptography—core expectations under Moldova’s cybersecurity framework.
law_refs: HG NU-49-MDED-2025: Autentificare și MFA (pct. 130–134); Criptografie (pct. 102–104); Igienă cibernetică și formare (pct. 94–101)
Legea nr. 48/2023: art. 11(2) – măsuri tehnice/organizatorice (inclusiv criptografie, control acces, comunicări securizate, igienă cibernetică)

resources.title: Google Workspace — About & set up DMARC

attack_vectors: Impersonation/spoofing of your domain in phishing campaigns
Delivery of unsigned/unaligned emails that bypass recipient filters
Compromise via third-party senders not included in SPF/DKIM
potential_impact: Fraud/phishing against customers and staff
Reputational damage and loss of trust
Email deliverability issues and business disruption

non_technical_steps: Inventory all senders: your mail server, cloud email (e.g., M365/Google), marketing platforms, CRMs, ticketing tools, etc.
Publish an SPF TXT record that includes every authorized sender (minimize DNS lookups; avoid ~all for long term).
Enable DKIM for each sender: generate keys, publish CNAME/TXT selectors in DNS, rotate keys periodically.
Publish a DMARC record with rua reporting and start at p=none; monitor aggregate reports for at least 2–4 weeks.
Tighten DMARC policy to p=quarantine then p=reject once alignment issues are fixed.
Maintain: update SPF/DKIM when adding/removing vendors; review DMARC reports monthly; rotate DKIM keys yearly.
guide.scope_caveats: SPF applies per domain; subdomains may need separate records. DMARC alignment must match From: domain. Include all third-party platforms that send mail as your domain.
guide.acceptance_summary: Not legally mandated by name, but strong evidence of controls for secure communications, cryptography, and basic hygiene. Keep evidence: DNS screenshots, DMARC aggregate report samples, and an email header showing SPF/DKIM/DMARC pass.

legal.requirement_summary: Email authentication supports required measures on authentication, cryptography, and user awareness. It’s a practical way to demonstrate you’ve implemented secure communications and cyber-hygiene measures expected by the framework.
article_refs: HG NU-49-MDED-2025: pct. 130–134 (Autentificare/MFA), pct. 102–104 (Criptografie), pct. 94–101 (Igienă & Formare)
Legea nr. 48/2023: art. 11(2) (măsuri tehnice/organizatorice: criptografie, politici de securitate, control acces, igienă cibernetică)
